title: Inclusive User Groups
overview: Highlight diverse user groups to avoid stereotypes and include marginalized voices.
purpose: Make user groups visible without oversimplifying. Check privilege and exclusion risks while building balanced user stories.

steps.title: Fill in Group Data
steps.description: Use real data on demographics, abilities, or safety.

steps.title: Check Privilege
steps.description: Use the Wheel of Power to assess advantages and disadvantages.

steps.title: Define Group Role
steps.description: Describe their relation to your product (e.g., daily user, decision-maker).

steps.title: Capture Needs & Pains
steps.description: List access barriers, time constraints, or usability issues.

steps.title: List Gains
steps.description: Identify benefits this group gets from your product.

steps.title: Write User Story
steps.description: Summarize with 'As a [role], I want [needs/pains], so that [gains]'.

prompts: I am designing for a user group: [describe group]. Suggest data points to collect (age, abilities, safety, etc.).
For this group [describe], list potential struggles and barriers when using [product/service].
Based on this description [group], analyze privileges and disadvantages they may face.
Create a user story for this group: [paste group info].
tips: Be specific (e.g., 'international student on a budget').
Base details on data, not assumptions.
Ask: Who is missing? Include marginalized groups.
Combine with Systemic Journey Maps for context.

title: Critical Reflection Cards
overview: Tool to foster critical thinking and help to create conscious digital products.
purpose: Explore how your design performs in different situations. Foster innovative problem solving that ensures effective and well-rounded strategies.

steps.title: Randomly select cards
steps.description: Randomly select two cards from each section, Individual, Social, and Environmental Impact.

steps.title: Reflect
steps.description: Test your design in the context of each card and reflect on your findings.

steps.title: Refine and document
steps.description: Write down your findings and think about potential improvements to your design.

steps.title: Repeat
steps.description: Repeat the process until you have a comprehensive understanding of your design.

prompts: Expand on this situation [situation]. Provide me with ways this situation could unfold.
Given my design [design] and this situation [situation], what are the potential impacts?
Considering [situation], which groups of users are most impacted?
tips: Use predefined questions to guide your thinking.
Try putting your self in the shoes of the user in these situations.
Think about the parts of your design that are most impacted or affected by the situation.
Consider if your findings change if you make the situation more or less extreme.

title: Systemic Journey Map
overview: Map user journeys step by step, including social and ecological impacts.
purpose: Break down experiences into clear phases. Link design choices to social and environmental effects, uncovering who is impacted and how.

steps.title: Define User Story
steps.description: Anchor the map with a user story or scenario.

steps.title: Set Journey Phases
steps.description: Break experiences into stages or steps.

steps.title: Capture Actions
steps.description: Write down what users do at each phase.

steps.title: Add Goals
steps.description: Describe what users want to achieve.

steps.title: Identify Pain Points
steps.description: List struggles or missing resources.

steps.title: List Gains
steps.description: Highlight benefits for users at each stage.

steps.title: Map Environmental Impacts
steps.description: Note effects on energy, waste, or resources.

steps.title: Map Social Impacts
steps.description: Record effects on inclusion, fairness, equity.

steps.title: Consider Orders of Impact
steps.description: Add first-, second-, and third-order effects.

steps.title: Add Data & Insights
steps.description: Include supporting data or findings.

input: Understanding of product or service flow
Awareness of social and ecological factors
prompts: I am mapping a journey for [project]. Suggest 5 phases and key actions for each.
For this journey [details], list goals, pains, and gains at each phase.
For this journey [details], identify possible social and environmental impacts.
Based on this journey map [details], describe first-, second-, and third-order impacts.

Consider impacts on community and environment.
Check against Conscious Digital Product Principles.
